Student-Faculty Camp
With such topics as "the non-validity of articles" and
the "advisability and advantage of having a News-Letter
faculty advisor" on the docket, we naturally ,went to the
Student-Faculty Camp last week fearing the worst. Much
to our surprise, this year's crop of student leaders saw
through the prejudicial phraseology of these topics (they
were suggested by last year's graduating major domos)
and concentrated on the real job of such a camp: communication between the various student organizations.
Hence, Student-Faculty Camp, Hopkins' first, was a success.
Of course, there were shortcomings. It was scheduled
during part of a Jewish holiday; the topics were not chosen
by the people who were going to discuss them; the camp
was so organized that the same students and faculty
traveled together through all four areas of discussion,
hearing the same attitudes and viewpoints for two straight
days, even though the topics themselves may have changed.
Nevertheless; it was gratifying to hear men like Dean
Evans, Dean Shaffer, Professor Hubbard, Dean Morrill,
Oz Steinwald, Lynn Poole, Dr. Swanson, Mr. Bilgrave,
Dr. Wickwire and others join student leaders to discuss
campus problems. No policies came from the camp, but
many ideas did. The News-Letter next week will examine
sonie of these.

The News-Letter wishes to welcome the class of 1964
and to wish them a rewarding four years at the Johns
Hopkins University. This is a unique institution, one justly
proud of its great traditions in all fields of learning. Unlike
the so-called prestige schools, the Hopkins exists primarily
to prepare men for scholarship. The ranks of academic
posts throughout the nation are filled by distinguished
Hopkins alumni.
Even those not preparing for academic posts, however,
will benefit from the atmosphere of this school; pervading
almost every classroom and laboratory is a constant,.
stimulating quest for knowledge. The best of the freshman class will progress in courses at their own rate and
will do original research while still undergraduates.
And judging from Admissions Office reports, this
freshman class is the brightest to hit Hopkins in Many
years. We hope their expected ."quality" is proved by their
achievements.
